title: 103_hr2396
content: The "Child Support Enforcement Improvements Act of 1993" allows depository institutions to provide financial records to state child support enforcement agencies without liability. Depository institutions are not liable for disclosing financial records to state child support enforcement agencies under federal or state law. State agencies can only disclose these records for the purpose of establishing, modifying, or enforcing child support obligations. Financial institutions can only disclose financial records for the purpose of establishing, modifying, or enforcing child support obligations. State officers or employees can be held liable for unauthorized disclosure of financial records, leading to civil damages in a district court of the United States. In cases of unauthorized disclosure of financial records by state officers or employees, individuals can seek damages in a US district court. Liability does not apply if the disclosure was made in good faith but erroneously interpreted. Damages awarded in such cases are determined by the court. The liability for unauthorized disclosure of financial records in US district court is determined by the greater of $1,000 per act or the actual damages plus punitive damages for willful or grossly negligent disclosure. The liability for unauthorized disclosure of financial records in US district court includes punitive damages, costs of the action, and definitions for depository institutions. The term "financial record" is defined by the Right to Financial Privacy Act of 1978, and the term "State child support enforcement agency" refers to a state agency that handles child support obligations. State child support enforcement agencies can access and use consumer reports in child support cases. State child support enforcement agencies can access consumer reports for establishing, modifying, or enforcing child support obligations if paternity has been established or acknowledged by the consumer. State child support enforcement agencies must provide written notice to consumers before obtaining their consumer report and certify fulfillment of requirements to the consumer reporting agency. The term 'State child support enforcement agency' is defined as a State agency that administers a program for establishing and enforcing child support obligations. SEC. 4. HEALTH CARE SUPPORT. In Child Support Orders, Section 466(a) of the Social Security Act is amended to include procedures for any child support order issued or modified by a court or administrative agency of the State. The State guidelines under Section 467 of the Social Security Act require expedited consideration of noncompliance with child support orders for health care coverage. Each State must establish guidelines for health care coverage of children under child support orders as a condition for plan approval. The guidelines should meet minimum standards set by the Secretary. The Secretary will establish minimum standards for guidelines on health care coverage for children under child support orders in each State. These guidelines will cover the contents of the order, responsibility for costs, and coverage details. The Secretary will establish minimum standards for guidelines on health care coverage for children under child support orders in each State, including the distribution of responsibility for costs, provision of health insurance, payment of insurance claims, rights of parents to insurance information, denial of coverage by insurance providers, and penalties for non-compliance. The Secretary will establish guidelines for health care coverage for children under child support orders, including distribution of costs, provision of insurance, penalties for non-compliance, and consideration of the best interests of the child. The State will establish guidelines for health care coverage for children under child support orders, considering the best interests of the child, parents' financial circumstances, and cost-effectiveness. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will issue proposed regulations within 9 months of the Act's enactment. Within 14 months of the Act's enactment, the Secretary of Health and Human Services will issue final regulations to implement amendments related to the Incentive Payments Program for dependent health insurance. The amendment to Section 458(b) of the Social Security Act allows for the inclusion of dependent health insurance provided due to successful enforcement of a support order. This provision considers the enforcement of a support order requiring an absent parent to obtain health insurance for their children as support collection, regardless of how the support is provided. The amendment to Section 458(b) of the Social Security Act allows for including dependent health insurance as support collection when a support order requiring an absent parent to obtain health insurance for their children is successfully enforced. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will prescribe necessary regulations within six months of the Act's enactment. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will prescribe regulations to implement the amendment made by the Act. A study will be conducted to determine incentives for States to enforce noncustodial parents' obligations to pay for children's health and dental expenses. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will report on the study regarding noncustodial parents' obligations to pay for children's health and dental expenses within 12 months of the Act's enactment. SEC. 5. ANNUAL REPORTS ON STATE COMPLIANCE WITH TIME LIMITS FOR CHILD SUPPORT ASSISTANCE. Amends Section 452(a)(10) of the Social Security Act to include compliance with established standards in state reports. SEC. 6. Employers must withhold wages to pay child support obligations and remit to state within 10 days; late payment penalty imposed. Employers must withhold wages to pay child support obligations and remit to state within 10 days; late payment penalty of $1,000 imposed if payment is not made on time. Penalties collected must be used for the operation of the State plan approved under section 454. Employers must remit withheld wages for child support obligations to the state within 10 days to avoid a $1,000 late payment penalty. Penalties collected are to be used for the operation of the State plan approved under section 454. The effective date for these amendments is the date of enactment of the Act, applying to wages paid on or after that date and payments under part D of title IV of the Social Security Act for calendar quarters beginning on or after that date. The State plan approved under section 454 of the Social Security Act may be delayed if State legislation is required to meet additional requirements imposed by the amendments. Failure to comply with the requirements solely based on the lack of necessary legislation is not considered a violation. The State plan approved under section 454 of the Social Security Act may be delayed if State legislation is needed to meet additional requirements. Failure to comply with the requirements solely due to the lack of necessary legislation is not considered a violation. SEC. 7. NATIONAL PARENT LOCATOR NETWORK. The Social Security Act is amended to expand the Parent Locator Service into a national network, allowing States to locate absent parents who owe child support or are subject to visitation orders by accessing records from other State agencies. The Parent Locator Service is expanded into a national network, allowing States to access records from other agencies to locate absent parents and obtain details of child support orders. The Parent Locator Service is expanded nationally to allow States to access records from other agencies to locate absent parents and obtain child support order details through online and batch processing. Requests can be directed to individual States, Federal agencies, or broadcasted to selected or all States. The Parent Locator Service allows States to access records from other agencies to locate absent parents and obtain child support order details. Requests can be directed to individual States, Federal agencies, or broadcasted to selected or all States with a maximum 48-hour turnaround time for information to be returned. Ready access to courts is provided through computer terminals in each court. HR 2396 IH----2
